content: The "Junk Fax Prevention Act of 2005" prohibits the transmission of unsolicited advertisements via fax unless there is an established business relationship with the recipient or the sender obtained the fax number through permission. The "Junk Fax Prevention Act of 2005" allows the transmission of unsolicited advertisements via fax if there is an established business relationship or if the recipient voluntarily provided their fax number for public distribution. The Junk Fax Prevention Act of 2005 allows unsolicited advertisements to be sent to fax machines with an established business relationship or if the sender had the recipient's fax number before the enactment date. Exceptions apply if the recipient requests not to receive future unsolicited advertisements. The definition of an established business relationship under the Junk Fax Prevention Act of 2005 is amended to include relationships with business subscribers under specific terms. The Junk Fax Prevention Act of 2005 is amended to include specific terms for established business relationships, with requirements for clear and conspicuous opt-out notices in unsolicited advertisements. The Junk Fax Prevention Act of 2005 requires unsolicited advertisement senders to provide a domestic contact telephone and fax number for recipients to request no further ads. The sender must also offer a cost-free mechanism for recipients to transmit such requests. Section 227 of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to require the FCC to submit an annual report to Congress on the enforcement of unsolicited advertisements sent to fax machines. SEC. 4. GAO STUDY OF JUNK FAX ENFORCEMENT. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on complaints received by the Federal Communications Commission regarding unsolicited advertisements sent to fax machines. The study will assess the Commission's mechanisms for handling complaints, enforcement success, communication with complainants, and the need for additional enforcement measures to protect consumers. The Comptroller General will examine the adequacy of existing statutory enforcement actions and remedies available to the Commission and consumers, the impact on senders of facsimiles, the potential increase in financial penalties for greater deterrent effect, and the establishment of penalties for repeat violators. A report on the study's results will be submitted to the Committee on Commerce, Science within 270 days of the Act's enactment. The study results will be submitted to the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation and the House Committee on Energy and Commerce.
